Context:
The Dental Assisting (Levels I and II) program offered by the college focuses on skills training in digital intra-oral imaging, laboratory procedures, infection prevention and control protocols, safety protocols, and business skills. Graduates of this program are eligible to apply to write the National Dental Assisting Examining Board (NDAEB) examination and, upon successful completion, can apply for certification with the Ontario Dental Assistants Association to work as a Level II dental assistant in Ontario. Interested students with lower marks may consider enrolling in the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109) program to develop new and strengthen existing skills in math, biology, chemistry, physics, and communication. This program does not guarantee entry into the advanced diploma program. The Dental Assisting program offers both on-site and off-site field education opportunities. In semester 1, students build the core skills of a dental assistant with mannequins in the on-site WAVE Dental Clinic and dental laboratories. In semester 2, students practice their skills with other students from the Restorative Dental Hygiene program and then progress to working with real patients both in the WAVE Clinic and off-site in the community. Field education sites include private dental practices, public health units, and teaching hospitals. Students have the opportunity to collaborate with one of the 12 George Brown College Child Care Centers to teach oral health education. Off-site travel may be required, and clinical hours include early mornings that can extend into the evening. Graduates of this program are eligible for career options in dentistry as dental assistants.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
1. The college offers a Dental Assisting (Levels I and II) program.
2. The skills taught in the program include digital intra-oral imaging, laboratory procedures, infection prevention and control protocols, safety protocols, and business skills.
3. Graduates are eligible to apply for certification with the Ontario Dental Assistants Association upon passing the NDAEB examination.
4. Interested students may enroll in the Pre-Health Sciences Pathway to Certificates and Diplomas (A109) program instead.
5. The program offers both on-site and off-site field education opportunities.
6. In semester 1, students build core skills with mannequins at the WAVE Dental Clinic.
7. In semester 2, students practice with other students and real patients in the community.
8. Field education sites include private dental practices, public health units, teaching hospitals, and child care centers.
9. Off-site travel may be required, and clinical hours can extend into the evening.
10. Graduates of the program are eligible for careers as dental assistants.

Context:
The Dental Assisting (Levels I and II) program graduates are eligible to take the National Dental Assisting Examining Board (NDAEB) examination for certification as a Level II Dental Assistant in Ontario. They can find employment in various sectors such as general and specialty private dental practices, public health units, hospital dental clinics, dental industry, armed forces, and insurance companies. Graduates may apply to other dental programs at George Brown College but must meet the minimum admission requirements and are not given priority admissions.

The required courses for the Dental Assisting program are spread across two semesters:

SEMESTER 1:
- DENT 1047: Dental Radiography I
- DENT 1137: Infection Prevention & Control for Dental Assisting
- DENT 1143: Introduction to the Dental Assisting Profession
- DENT 1147: Dental Sciences I
- DENT 1149: Dental Materials Theory I
- DENT 1152: Clinical Foundations Theory I
- DENT 1153: Oral Health & Prevention I
- DENT 1154: Clinical Foundations Practical I
- DENT 1155: Laboratory Procedures I
- COMM 1000 (or COMM 2000): Introduction to College Communication or Communicating Across Contexts

SEMESTER 2:
- DENT 1049: Business Office Skills
- DENT 1051: Dental Radiography II
- DENT 1148: Dental Assisting Consolidation
- DENT 1156: Patient Management
- DENT 1157: Preparation for Community Placement
- DENT 2147: Dental Sciences II
- DENT 2149: Dental Materials Theory II
- DENT 2152: Clinical Foundations Theory II
- DENT 2153: Oral Health & Prevention II.

Context:
Program Offered: Dental Assisting
Semesters: Fall 2023 for domestic students, Fall 2024 for international students
Courses: Clinical Foundation Theory II (DENT 2153), Oral Health & Prevention II (DENT 2154), Clinical Foundations Practical II (DENT 2155), Laboratory Procedures II, Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000)
Class Schedule: Full-time program. Classes may be scheduled from 7:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Monday to Friday. Students are expected to be on campus at least four days out of the week.
Program Learning Outcomes: Maintain client and personal safety, Contribute to comprehensive client profile development, Contribute to comprehensive plan for oral health services, Provide oral health services and programs, Contribute to evaluation and reporting, Act professionally and competently, Maintain client records and manage office procedures (compliance with relevant legislation and regulations)
Tuition & Fees: Domestic students - $7,143.00 for two semesters, International students - $21,380.00 for two semesters (Fees are subject to change and do not include books, which are to be purchased separately)

Context: The program at George Brown College has additional costs not included in tuition, such as course manuals, laboratory/clinical attire, personal protective equipment, and potential international fees. International students should refer to specific pages for fees and admission requirements. Financial assistance is available through OSAP for those who meet the eligibility criteria. Applicants need grades of 60% or higher in grade 12 English, grade 11 or 12 Math, and grade 11 Biology (or their equivalent) for admission. Mature students may take an Admissions Assessment or upgrade to achieve the required credits. Course exemptions are possible with college or university credits. International students should refer to specific pages for country-specific admission requirements. Students must meet and complete all mandatory Pre-placement requirements upon acceptance into the program, which can take up to 10 to 12 weeks. Proof of medical records (such as TDAP shot, MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, and Two-Step TB Skin Test) and a clear Vulnerable Sector Check (renewed every year) are also required.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Dental Assisting (Levels I and II) Program S113 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
1. Vulnerable Sector Check: required for students in the program, renewed every year, typically takes 2-3 months but can take up to 8 months. Students are responsible for ensuring the check covers "individuals being employed and/or volunteering who will be working with vulnerable person(s)". The original copy must be kept by the student.
2. Basic Life Support certificate: required, renewed every year.
3. Annual flu shot and mask fit test: required, renewed every two years.
4. Proof of COVID-19 vaccination: recommended for oral health care workers and some students may be required for placements in hospitals, long term care facilities and community agencies. Students who are not vaccinated may not be able to attend external clinical or field placements. The onsite dental clinic does not require vaccination but it is highly recommended.
5. Use of PPE: required in all onsite clinics.
6. Health policies and non-academic requirements: designed to protect clients and vulnerable populations, students who do not comply with the programâ€™s health policy and non-academic requirements or who do not submit all required documentation by deadlines will be excluded from clinical practicum, which may jeopardize their academic standing and successful completion of the program.
7. All costs, service fees and fines associated with overall health requirements are the responsibility of the student.
8. To download the mandatory Pre-placement health form and for more details, go to the Clinical Pre-placement website.

Context:
The text mentions several programs offered by George Brown College: Dental Hygiene (S134), Dental Technology (S100), and Denturism (S101). Students who are unable to provide a clear Vulnerable Sector Check may not be able to start their field or clinical placement, which could prevent them from completing the program and securing employment. The fees for the vulnerable sector check vary, and students can find more information on the Clinical Pre-placement website or by contacting sdhprograms@georgebrown.ca. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. For program information, contact 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email sdhprograms@georgebrown.ca. Potential applicants can also book a campus tour, attend an info session, and sign up to receive tailored resources to help with their application process.
